title: 114_s1865
content: The "Anna Westin Act of 2015" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, training and education, public service announcements, and clarification of existing parity law. The Congress finds that anorexia nervosa poses a high risk of death, with significant health consequences such as osteoporosis and cardiac issues. Approximately 14.5 million people in the US suffer from eating disorders, with a high rate of comorbidity with other illnesses. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by self-starvation and weight loss. Anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder are serious eating disorders with associated health consequences. Anorexia nervosa is linked to heart failure, kidney failure, osteoporosis, and a higher risk of suicide. Bulimia nervosa can lead to cardiac, gastrointestinal, and dental problems. Binge eating disorder involves frequent episodes of uncontrolled overeating. Binge eating is often associated with obesity, high blood pressure, elevated cholesterol levels, increased risk of various cancers, diabetes, and arthritic damage. Many individuals exhibit symptoms of anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, or binge eating disorder. Eating disorders are more common in women, but occur in men as well. Academic evidence shows a connection between the use of very thin models in advertising and consumer behavior. Eating disorders affect all demographics in the US and are linked to psychological issues like depression and substance abuse. Hospitalizations for eating disorders in children under 12 rose by 119% from 1999 to 2006. The Act defines "eating disorder" to include various conditions like anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Act also addresses training and education. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will update the BodyWise Handbook with information on eating disorders for males and females. This information will be incorporated into the BodyWorks obesity prevention program curriculum and training modules. The updated resources will be made publicly available. The BodyWise Handbook, fact sheets, and resource lists, along with the BodyWorks obesity prevention program, will be updated to include information on eating disorders for males and females. These resources will be available for universities and nonprofit entities for educational purposes. SEC. 6. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to integrate training on eating disorders into existing curricula for healthcare professionals. This includes early intervention, levels of treatment, referral procedures, prevention strategies, and treatment methods. Entities must submit an application with a plan for fund usage and training evaluation. Entities receiving grants must use the funds to develop evidence-based training programs on identifying, intervening, and treating eating disorders. Training should cover prevention strategies, early intervention, and comprehensive assessment of individuals at risk for eating disorders. The grant recipients must develop evidence-based training programs on identifying, intervening, and treating eating disorders. This includes conducting comprehensive assessments of individual and familial health risk factors, treatment plans, and evaluating the effectiveness of the training provided. SEC. 7. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR SCHOOL AND HIGHER EDUCATION PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary shall award grants to eligible entities for educational seminars on early identification, intervention, and prevention of eating disorders, and to provide resources to affected individuals. Eligible entities must conduct seminars considering materials from the BodyWise initiative and relevant research. Eligible entities include states, territories, tribes, and organizations. The curr_chunk states that eligible entities for grants include public or private educational institutions, as defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will conduct public service announcements to educate the public on eating disorders, including types, seriousness, prevention, and effects of media on self-esteem. Collaboration with centers of excellence and national nonprofit resources supporting individuals affected by eating disorders is required. SEC. 9. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF EXISTING PARITY LAW. Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act and Section 712 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act are amended to include provisions regarding mental health and substance use disorder benefits, specifically addressing permanent exclusions and residential treatment. The Public Health Service Act and Employee Retirement Income Security Act are amended to address mental health and substance use disorder benefits, including permanent exclusions and residential treatment. The amendments address mental health and substance use disorder benefits, prohibiting permanent exclusions for specific conditions and including residential treatment in the coverage. The scope of mental health and addiction services remains unchanged under existing laws. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendments; existing funds will be used instead.
